issue.title: Inconsistent filesystem operations after renames when file watch service is enabled

labels.name: team-Core
labels.description: Skyframe, bazel query, BEP, options parsing, bazelrc

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
### Description of the bug:


With `--watchfs` enabled, a temporary rename of a source directory and then renaming it back can leave Bazel in a stale state where it continues to error as follows:
```
ERROR: Skipping '//...': error loading package under directory '': no such package 'src/main/java/com/example/app': Inconsistent filesystem operations. /home/user/p/test/hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds/src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main is no longer an existing directory. Did you delete it during the build? The results of the build are not guaranteed to be correct. You should probably run 'bazel clean' and investigate the filesystem inconsistency (likely due to filesystem updates concurrent with the build)
ERROR: error loading package under directory '': no such package 'src/main/java/com/example/app': Inconsistent filesystem operations. /home/user/p/test/hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds/src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main is no longer an existing directory. Did you delete it during the build? The results of the build are not guaranteed to be correct. You should probably run 'bazel clean' and investigate the filesystem inconsistency (likely due to filesystem updates concurrent with the build)
```

### Which category does this issue belong to?

Core

### What's the simplest, easiest way to reproduce this bug? Please provide a minimal example if possible.


1. download [hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22079998/hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds.zip)
2. run demo.sh
```
set -euxo pipefail

bazelisk shutdown

bazelisk build //... --watchfs
mv src/main/java/com/example/app/src/{main,main2}
bazelisk build //... --watchfs
mv src/main/java/com/example/app/src/{main2,main}
bazelisk build //... --watchfs && echo OK || {
    echo FAIL, try again after shutdown
    bazelisk shutdown
    bazelisk build //... --watchfs
    exit 1
}
```

### Which operating system are you running Bazel on?


Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS

### What is the output of `bazel info release`?


release 8.3.1

### If `bazel info release` returns `development version` or `(@non-git)`, tell us how you built Bazel.


_No response_

### What's the output of `git remote get-url origin; git rev-parse HEAD` ?


```text

```

### If this is a regression, please try to identify the Bazel commit where the bug was introduced with bazelisk --bisect.


_No response_

### Have you found anything relevant by searching the web?

#26863

### Any other information, logs, or outputs that you want to share?

```
+ bazelisk shutdown
Starting local Bazel server (8.3.1) and connecting to it...
+ bazelisk build //... --watchfs
Starting local Bazel server (8.3.1) and connecting to it...
INFO: Analyzed 3 targets (84 packages loaded, 4092 targets configured).
INFO: Found 3 targets...
INFO: Elapsed time: 8.610s, Critical Path: 1.41s
INFO: 2 processes: 11 action cache hit, 1 internal, 1 worker.
INFO: Build completed successfully, 2 total actions
+ mv src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main2
+ bazelisk build //... --watchfs
INFO: Analyzed 3 targets (1 packages loaded, 2 targets configured).
INFO: Found 3 targets...
INFO: Elapsed time: 0.556s, Critical Path: 0.14s
INFO: 2 processes: 5 action cache hit, 1 internal, 1 worker.
INFO: Build completed successfully, 2 total actions
+ mv src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main2 src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main
+ bazelisk build //... --watchfs
WARNING: Target pattern parsing failed.
ERROR: Skipping '//...': error loading package under directory '': no such package 'src/main/java/com/example/app': Inconsistent filesystem operations. /path/to/hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds/src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main is no longer an existing directory. Did you delete it during the build? The results of the build are not guaranteed to be correct. You should probably run 'bazel clean' and investigate the filesystem inconsistency (likely due to filesystem updates concurrent with the build)
ERROR: error loading package under directory '': no such package 'src/main/java/com/example/app': Inconsistent filesystem operations. /path/to/hello-bazel-java_colocated_builds/src/main/java/com/example/app/src/main is no longer an existing directory. Did you delete it during the build? The results of the build are not guaranteed to be correct. You should probably run 'bazel clean' and investigate the filesystem inconsistency (likely due to filesystem updates concurrent with the build)
INFO: Elapsed time: 0.120s
INFO: 0 processes.
ERROR: Build did NOT complete successfully
+ echo FAIL, try again after shutdown
FAIL, try again after shutdown
+ bazelisk shutdown
+ bazelisk build //... --watchfs
Starting local Bazel server (8.3.1) and connecting to it...
INFO: Analyzed 3 targets (84 packages loaded, 4092 targets configured).
INFO: Found 3 targets...
INFO: Elapsed time: 5.325s, Critical Path: 1.42s

INFO: Build completed successfully, 2 total actions
+ exit 1
```

body:
The tests in https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/pull/26920 show that this solution isn't sufficient: otherwise stale `FileStateValue`s can be incorrectly resurrected if their containing directory exists again.

It seems like https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/30ea84df62ddb31e73aabeedfb62afdb3dc80607/src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/skyframe/FileSystemValueCheckerInferringAncestors.java#L68-L69
can only be guaranteed if a removed directory with no indication of changes to any child results in a full traversal of all `FileStateValue`s, invalidating those that lie under it.

The alternative would be to store all encountered files in `WatchServiceDiffAwareness`, not just the directories.

issue.title: Invalidate subtrees when a directory is deleted

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
`FileSystemValueCheckerInferringAncestors` claims that it is resilient to diffs which only report the root of a deleted subtree, but this wasn't true. Stale `FileStateValue`s and `DirectoryListingStateValue`s could linger around after moving an entire directory tree out of the workspace watched with `--watchfs`.

This is fixed by invalidating all FSVs and DLSVs under any deleted directory. Since these values and their keys do not depend on their parents, this requires a manual walk of the entire graph, making use of a prefix-free sorted map to speed up lookups per key.

Fixes #26863
Fixes #26866

body:
To immortalize a privtate discussion with @fmeum : this is indeed tricky, one should remove all `FileStateValue`s under a directory of the directory is deleted (and for good measure, I guess if it's created also although in theory, in that case there aren't any)

Unfortunately, Bazel doesn't keep track of the file system tree like this; as far as Skyframe is concerned, each `FileStateValue` is independent (unlike `FileValue`s which depend on their parents). So the best think I can think of is that if `WatchService` detects that a directory is deleted (or maybe created), iterate over all nodes in Skyframe and  mark the ones under it as dirty.

The silver lining of this cloud is that this shouldn't be too slow, since it's a CPU-only operation, no I/O is required.
